keyTakeAways: The NBA season opens with a record 135 players born outside the U.S., from 43 countries, with 71 from Europe — the highest number from Europe ever.
Canada leads in non-U.S. players with 23, followed by France (19) and Australia (13).
The Atlanta Hawks open the season with 10 international players, tying an NBA record.
All 30 NBA teams have at least one international player on their opening-night rosters.
The NBA and FIBA are in talks to create a new league in Europe, potentially launching as early as 2027.
Players born outside the U.S. have won the last seven NBA MVP awards, a streak unmatched in history.
Oklahoma City’s Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canadian) and Serbian Nikola Jokić are among the international players who have won the MVP award.
The NBA is expected to finalize a new All-Star Game format featuring U.S. players vs. international players in a tournament.
The Brooklyn Nets have the youngest roster in the league, with no player among the top 100 active scorers, and their total career starts are significantly lower than top players.
There are seven players named 'Jordan' and five named 'Nikola' and five named 'James' across the league, indicating a cultural trend in naming after famous figures.
Orlando Robinson is the only player known to wear his first name on the front and last name on the back of his jersey.
The Bucks have three Antetokounmpo brothers — Giannis, Thanasis, and Alex — highlighting a family legacy in the league.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 NBA season opens with a record 135 players born outside the U.S., from 43 countries, including 71 from Europe — the most ever from that continent. Canada leads with 23 international players, followed by France (19) and Australia (13). All 30 teams have at least one international player, and the Atlanta Hawks tie an NBA record with 10 international players on their roster. The NBA and FIBA are in talks to launch a new European league by 2027, signaling a major expansion of the game beyond North America. The last seven NBA MVPs have been awarded to players born outside the U.S., highlighting a shift toward global talent. The league is also finalizing a new All-Star Game format featuring U.S. vs. international players. Notably, the Brooklyn Nets have one of the youngest rosters, with no players among the top 100 scorers, while international players like Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (Canada), Nikola Jokić (Serbia), and Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece) exemplify the global nature of the game. Cultural naming trends, such as multiple 'Jordan' and 'Nikola' players, and unique jersey choices like Orlando Robinson’s, add a human dimension to the narrative.
title: NBA Season Opens with Record Global Player Representation and Talks of a European League
